guide.conclusion: If you are having trouble finding laser-cut snowflakes, a simple style in maple can be found here, or try getting a friend or two to go in on a purchase of this lovely set. You can also forgo all the Mod Podging and pick up this beautiful brass set from Crate and Barrel; just don't forget to add the felt!

guide.introduction: For the past few years, I have seen pretty little laser-cut ornaments in the craft stores. Recently, on a paint run to Michael's, I discovered an assortment of lovely unstained snowflakes. They were so pretty, I scooped up about a dozen or so. They are the perfect size to place a hot mug of tea or coffee on so I thought, "Why not?" Here's my how-to for an easy-yet-elegant holiday gift that would be especially delightful as a hostess gift.
guide.introduction_rendered:
For the past few years, I have seen pretty little laser-cut ornaments in the craft stores. Recently, on a paint run to Michael's, I discovered an assortment of lovely unstained snowflakes. They were so pretty, I scooped up about a dozen or so. They are the perfect size to place a hot mug of tea or coffee on so I thought, "Why not?" Here's my how-to for an easy-yet-elegant holiday gift that would be especially delightful as a hostess gift.

Relevant parts
  • 4 Laser-cut snowflake ornaments
  • Wool-felt blend (1-4 colors)
  • Mod Podge Hard Coat
Tools
  • Compass
  • Paint brush
  • Sandpaper (fine-grade)
  • Scissors
  • Scrap paper
  • Wax paper

lines.text: If your laser-cut pieces have ties or ribbon on them, snip them off.
lines.text_raw: If your laser-cut pieces have ties or ribbon on them, snip them off.

lines.text: If there is a sticker label, peel that off as well. If you are having a problem removing all the stick of the sticker, try looping a piece of sticky tape, sticky side out, around your finger and use that tack to grab any stubborn stick still remaining on your wood pieces.
lines.text_raw: If there is a sticker label, peel that off as well. If you are having a problem removing all the stick of the sticker, try looping a piece of sticky tape, sticky side out, around your finger and use that tack to grab any stubborn stick still remaining on your wood pieces.

lines.text: Set up a mess-happy workspace to give your pieces their first hard-coat. I used wax paper on top of a cookie sheet.
lines.text_raw: Set up a mess-happy workspace to give your pieces their first hard-coat. I used wax paper on top of a cookie sheet.

lines.text: Give each piece an even coat of the Mod Podge Hard Coat.
lines.text_raw: Give each piece an even coat of the Mod Podge Hard Coat.

lines.text: Make sure you are using the Hard Coat or other sealer that is water-resistant and weather-proof. We're going to be camping many a happy glass full of something liquid on these, so they need to be waterproof.
lines.text_raw: Make sure you are using the Hard Coat or other sealer that is water-resistant and weather-proof. We're going to be camping many a happy glass full of something liquid on these, so they need to be waterproof.

lines.text: Go slow and keep your brush barely wet, otherwise all the nooks and crannies of your pieces may decide to collect some of that Mod Podge for their own.
lines.text_raw: Go slow and keep your brush barely wet, otherwise all the nooks and crannies of your pieces may decide to collect some of that Mod Podge for their own.

lines.text: Set the pieces aside to dry a couple of hours. If you find globs of the hardcoat gooping up your nooks and crannies, use a toothpick to dab and scoop them clean.
lines.text_raw: Set the pieces aside to dry a couple of hours. If you find globs of the hardcoat gooping up your nooks and crannies, use a toothpick to dab and scoop them clean.

lines.text: Once they are dry, grab yourself a small piece of fine-grade sandpaper and give your wood cut a little sandpaper love.
lines.text_raw: Once they are dry, grab yourself a small piece of fine-grade sandpaper and give your wood cut a little sandpaper love.

lines.text: Dust off any debris.
lines.text_raw: Dust off any debris.

lines.text: Give it another coat, dry, and sand again.
lines.text_raw: Give it another coat, dry, and sand again.

lines.text: Top it off with one final coat, for a total of three coats of Mod Podge on your wood cuts.
lines.text_raw: Top it off with one final coat, for a total of three coats of Mod Podge on your wood cuts.

lines.text: Count on this part as being an all-day project.
lines.text_raw: Count on this part as being an all-day project.

steps.title: Make pattern for the felt backing

lines.text: Measure your wood pieces with a compass, unless you have found yourself something with angles (then use a ruler).
lines.text_raw: Measure your wood pieces with a compass, unless you have found yourself something with angles (then use a ruler).

lines.text: On a scrap piece of paper, make a pattern for your backing felt and cut it out.
lines.text_raw: On a scrap piece of paper, make a pattern for your backing felt and cut it out.

lines.text: Pin pattern to your felt pieces and cut.
lines.text_raw: Pin pattern to your felt pieces and cut.

lines.text: I used two shades of blue that will be glued together to create a wee bit more stability for your coasters. You can use all the same color of felt or four different colors; it's all up to you.
lines.text_raw: I used two shades of blue that will be glued together to create a wee bit more stability for your coasters. You can use all the same color of felt or four different colors; it's all up to you.

lines.text: If your wooden pieces measure 4" across, you will need two sheets of felt, 9" x 9".
lines.text_raw: If your wooden pieces measure 4" across, you will need two sheets of felt, 9" x 9".

lines.text: A wool felt or wool blend is preferable. Acrylic felt will work as well, but I find wool and wool blends come in prettier colors. I picked up my felt from Lupin at etsy.com.
lines.text_raw: A wool felt or wool blend is preferable. Acrylic felt will work as well, but I find wool and wool blends come in prettier colors. I picked up my felt from Lupin at etsy.com.

lines.text: Layer up two circles of felt and glue them together by dabbing small dots of tacky glue along the edges.
lines.text_raw: Layer up two circles of felt and glue them together by dabbing small dots of tacky glue along the edges.

lines.text: You can anchor them together with clothespins until they dry.
lines.text_raw: You can anchor them together with clothespins until they dry.

lines.text: A quick press with a hot iron will smooth out any bumps and wrinkles.
lines.text_raw: A quick press with a hot iron will smooth out any bumps and wrinkles.

lines.text: Apply wee dots of tacky glue to the back of your wood cut, position over felt circle and gently push down.
lines.text_raw: Apply wee dots of tacky glue to the back of your wood cut, position over felt circle and gently push down.

lines.text: Repeat for each shape and set aside to dry.
lines.text_raw: Repeat for each shape and set aside to dry.

lines.text: Admire your crafty work and wrap 'em up, or make yourself a hot cuppa somethin' and relax.
lines.text_raw: Admire your crafty work and wrap 'em up, or make yourself a hot cuppa somethin' and relax.

guide.summary: Make a simple snowflake coaster out of felt and a pre-cut wooden snowflake.
